summary:
I like working cross functionally in the early phases (I,  II) of biomedical technologies. I am driven by understanding biomedical problems from technical, basic physiological, clinical workflow and regulatory perspectives. All of my research projects have been at the intersection of electrically active system design, basic physiology (cardiac and briefly neuro), signal processing, prototype development, pre-clinical validation, and/or scientific communication. 

Between academia and industry, I have contributed towards problems related to electrophysiology, bio algorithms, bioelectronics, biosensors, and hypothesis driven validation activities. I have worked in in vitro, in vivo, ex vivo and acute lab settings.
geoRegion: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States

currentPositions.description: ■	Driving translational R&D work related to characterization of requirements for cardiac conduction system CRT-P and CRT-D leads.
currentPositions.title: Postdoctoral Research Associate

projects.description: Modeled the function of Human Superior Colliculus to classify events considering visual and auditory inputs in Matlab.
projects.title: Robotic vision using Bayers model

projects.description: Used MATLAB, VMTK, and Paraview to generate stress estimates when a stent model is inserted in the imaging reconstructed model blood vessel.
projects.title: Stress indicator heat-map for stents inside blood vessels using structures created from segmented images

projects.description: Adopted 3 algorithms to discriminate speech signal vs. music signal without using any Matlab toolboxes. Results indicated that the spectral centroid variance technique had the highest classification accuracy (93.34%).
projects.title: Speech vs Music signal discrimination

projects.description: Used interrupts/timers/pulse width modulation, implemented I2C, USART, Bluetooth serial communication, performed ADC/DAC, interacted with sensors/actuators using proportional-integral software on ARM Cortex-M0 controller.
projects.title: Embedded system design using ARM Cortex M0

headline: Ph.D. | Scientist | Biomedical Engineer
location: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States

publications.name: Optogenetic modulation of cortical neurons using organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs)
In Vitro/Ex Vivo Investigation of Modified Utah Electrode Array to Selectively Sense and Pace the Sub-Surface Cardiac His Bundle
A real-time system for selectively sensing and pacing the His-bundle during sinus rhythm and ventricular fibrillation

publications.description: The potential of pacing and capturing the His-Purkinje system (HPS) to synchronize VF wavefronts was not known even though the HPS is thought to be electrically linked during VF. In the study, the effect of selective His Bundle (HB) pacing was compared with nearby working myocardial (WM) pacing on the left ventricular (LV) endocardial activation rates.
publications.name: During Early VF in Rabbit Hearts, His Bundle Pacing is Less Effective Than Working Myocardial Pacing in Modulating Left Ventricular Activation Rates

message.text:
Dear Network,

Left Bundle Branch Area (LBBA) is becoming the preferred pacing target for cardiac resynchronization therapy and anti-bradycardia pacing in cases of reduced ejection fraction. Unlike previous permanent cardiac pacing targets, conduction system lead placement relies on simultaneous imaging and electrophysiological feedback.

Over the past several months, I have started systematic characterization of the top three workflow issues in LBBA lead placement. In line with this, I will be sharing our team's findings at the Heart Rhythm Society meeting in Boston next week. I look forward to connecting with anyone interested!

Title: Characteristics of Left Bundle Branch Area Pacing Using a Multi-electrode Lead
Session: PO-484326 Poster Session V
Date: 18th May, 2024
Time: 1:30 PM – 3:30 PM

It is a privilege to work alongside the interdisciplinary team of scientists, engineers, and physicians like Kyoichiro Yazaki MD PhD, Robert Hitchcock PhD, Derek Dosdall PhD, and Ravi Ranjan MD PhD.
